trans-unit.source: How to: Configure Firewall Settings | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: How to: Configure Firewall Settings | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Configure the firewall for IP addresses that access Azure SQL databases.
trans-unit.target: Configure the firewall for IP addresses that access Azure SQL databases.

trans-unit.source: How to: Configure firewall settings on SQL Database
trans-unit.target: How to: Configure firewall settings on SQL Database

trans-unit.source: Microsoft Azure SQL Database uses firewall rules to allow connections to your servers and databases.
trans-unit.target: Microsoft Azure SQL Database uses firewall rules to allow connections to your servers and databases.

trans-unit.source: You can define server-level and database-level firewall settings for the master or a user database in your Azure SQL Database server to selectively allow access to the database.
trans-unit.target: You can define server-level and database-level firewall settings for the master or a user database in your Azure SQL Database server to selectively allow access to the database.

trans-unit.source: Important To allow applications from Azure to connect to your database server, Azure connections must be enabled.
trans-unit.target: Important To allow applications from Azure to connect to your database server, Azure connections must be enabled.

trans-unit.source: For more information about firewall rules and enabling connections from Azure, see <link><linkText>Azure SQL Database Firewall</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: For more information about firewall rules and enabling connections from Azure, see <link><linkText>Azure SQL Database Firewall</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: Server-Level Firewall Rules
trans-unit.target: Server-Level Firewall Rules

trans-unit.source: Server-level firewall rules can be created and managed through the Microsoft Azure Management Portal, Transact-SQL, Azure PowerShell, or REST API.
trans-unit.target: Server-level firewall rules can be created and managed through the Microsoft Azure Management Portal, Transact-SQL, Azure PowerShell, or REST API.

trans-unit.source: Manage Server-Level Firewall Rules through the New Azure Portal
trans-unit.target: Manage Server-Level Firewall Rules through the New Azure Portal

trans-unit.source: Visit the Azure Portal at https://portal.azure.com and sign-in with your Azure Administrator or Contributor account.
trans-unit.target: Visit the Azure Portal at https://portal.azure.com and sign-in with your Azure Administrator or Contributor account.

trans-unit.source: On the left banner, click BROWSE ALL, scroll down, and then click SQL servers.
trans-unit.target: On the left banner, click BROWSE ALL, scroll down, and then click SQL servers.

trans-unit.source: Click the server that you want to configure firewall rules for in the list of SQL Server displayed.
trans-unit.target: Click the server that you want to configure firewall rules for in the list of SQL Server displayed.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>firewall</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>firewall</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the server blade, click Settings at the top of the blade, and then click Firewall to open the Firewall Settings blade for the server.
trans-unit.target: In the server blade, click Settings at the top of the blade, and then click Firewall to open the Firewall Settings blade for the server.

trans-unit.source: Add or change a firewall rule.
trans-unit.target: Add or change a firewall rule.

trans-unit.source: To add the IP address of the current computer, click Add Client IP at the top of the blade.
trans-unit.target: To add the IP address of the current computer, click Add Client IP at the top of the blade.

trans-unit.source: To add additional IP addresses, type in the RULE NAME, START IP address, and END IP address.
trans-unit.target: To add additional IP addresses, type in the RULE NAME, START IP address, and END IP address.

trans-unit.source: To modify an existing rule, click and change any of the fields in the rule.
trans-unit.target: To modify an existing rule, click and change any of the fields in the rule.

trans-unit.source: To delete an existing rule, click the rule, click the ellipsis (…)
trans-unit.target: To delete an existing rule, click the rule, click the ellipsis (…)

trans-unit.source: at the end of the row, and then click Delete.
trans-unit.target: at the end of the row, and then click Delete.

trans-unit.source: Click Save at the top of the Firewall Settings blade to save the changes.
trans-unit.target: Click Save at the top of the Firewall Settings blade to save the changes.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>firewall blade</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>firewall blade</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Manage Server-Level Firewall Rules through Management Portal
trans-unit.target: Manage Server-Level Firewall Rules through Management Portal

trans-unit.source: From the Management Portal, click SQL Databases.
trans-unit.target: From the Management Portal, click SQL Databases.

trans-unit.source: All databases and their corresponding servers are listed here.
trans-unit.target: All databases and their corresponding servers are listed here.

trans-unit.source: Click Servers at the top of the page.
trans-unit.target: Click Servers at the top of the page.

trans-unit.source: Click the arrow beside the server for which you want to manage firewall rules.
trans-unit.target: Click the arrow beside the server for which you want to manage firewall rules.

trans-unit.source: Click Configure at the top of the page.
trans-unit.target: Click Configure at the top of the page.

trans-unit.source: To add the current computer, click Add to the Allowed IP Addresses.
trans-unit.target: To add the current computer, click Add to the Allowed IP Addresses.

trans-unit.source: To add additional IP addresses, type in the Rule Name, Start IP Address, and End IP Address.
trans-unit.target: To add additional IP addresses, type in the Rule Name, Start IP Address, and End IP Address.

trans-unit.source: To modify an existing rule, click any of the fields in the rule and modify.
trans-unit.target: To modify an existing rule, click any of the fields in the rule and modify.

trans-unit.source: To delete an existing rule, hover over the rule until the X appears at the end of the row.
trans-unit.target: To delete an existing rule, hover over the rule until the X appears at the end of the row.

trans-unit.source: Click X to remove the rule.
trans-unit.target: Click X to remove the rule.

trans-unit.source: Click Save at the bottom of the page to save the changes.
trans-unit.target: Click Save at the bottom of the page to save the changes.

trans-unit.source: Manage Server-Level Firewall Rules through Transact-SQL
trans-unit.target: Manage Server-Level Firewall Rules through Transact-SQL

trans-unit.source: Launch a query window through the Management Portal or through SQL Server Management Studio.
trans-unit.target: Launch a query window through the Management Portal or through SQL Server Management Studio.

trans-unit.source: Verify you are connected to the master database.
trans-unit.target: Verify you are connected to the master database.

trans-unit.source: Server-level firewall rules can be selected, created, updated, or deleted from within the query window.
trans-unit.target: Server-level firewall rules can be selected, created, updated, or deleted from within the query window.

trans-unit.source: To create or update server-level firewall rules, execute the sp_set_firewall rule stored procedure.
trans-unit.target: To create or update server-level firewall rules, execute the sp_set_firewall rule stored procedure.

trans-unit.source: The following example enables a range of IP addresses on the server Contoso.<html></html>Start by seeing what rules already exist.
trans-unit.target: The following example enables a range of IP addresses on the server Contoso.<html></html>Start by seeing what rules already exist.

trans-unit.source: Next, add a firewall rule.
trans-unit.target: Next, add a firewall rule.

trans-unit.source: To delete a server-level firewall rule, execute the sp_delete_firewall_rule stored procedure.
trans-unit.target: To delete a server-level firewall rule, execute the sp_delete_firewall_rule stored procedure.

trans-unit.source: The following example deletes the rule named ContosoFirewallRule.
trans-unit.target: The following example deletes the rule named ContosoFirewallRule.

trans-unit.source: Manage Server-Level Firewall Rules through Azure PowerShell
trans-unit.target: Manage Server-Level Firewall Rules through Azure PowerShell

trans-unit.source: Launch Azure PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: Launch Azure PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: Server-level firewall rules can be created, updated, and deleted using Azure PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: Server-level firewall rules can be created, updated, and deleted using Azure PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: To create a new server-level firewall rule, execute the New-AzureSqlDatabaseServerFirewallRule cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: To create a new server-level firewall rule, execute the New-AzureSqlDatabaseServerFirewallRule cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: The following example enables a range of IP addresses on the server Contoso.
trans-unit.target: The following example enables a range of IP addresses on the server Contoso.

trans-unit.source: To modify an existing server-level firewall rule, execute the Set-AzureSqlDatabaseServerFirewallRule cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: To modify an existing server-level firewall rule, execute the Set-AzureSqlDatabaseServerFirewallRule cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: The following example changes the range of acceptable IP addresses for the rule named ContosoFirewallRule.
trans-unit.target: The following example changes the range of acceptable IP addresses for the rule named ContosoFirewallRule.

trans-unit.source: To delete an existing server-level firewall rule, execute the Remove-AzureSqlDatabaseServerFirewallRule cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: To delete an existing server-level firewall rule, execute the Remove-AzureSqlDatabaseServerFirewallRule cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: The following example deletes the rule named ContosoFirewallRule.
trans-unit.target: The following example deletes the rule named ContosoFirewallRule.

trans-unit.source: Manage Server-Level Firewall Rules through REST API
trans-unit.target: Manage Server-Level Firewall Rules through REST API

trans-unit.source: Managing firewall rules through REST API must be authenticated.
trans-unit.target: Managing firewall rules through REST API must be authenticated.

trans-unit.source: For information, see Authenticating Service Management Requests.
trans-unit.target: For information, see Authenticating Service Management Requests.

trans-unit.source: Server-level rules can be created, updated, or deleted using REST API
trans-unit.target: Server-level rules can be created, updated, or deleted using REST API

trans-unit.source: To create or update a server-level firewall rule, execute the POST method using the following:
trans-unit.target: To create or update a server-level firewall rule, execute the POST method using the following:

trans-unit.source: Request Body
trans-unit.target: Request Body

trans-unit.source: To remove an existing server-level firewall rule, execute the DELETE method using the following:
trans-unit.target: To remove an existing server-level firewall rule, execute the DELETE method using the following:

trans-unit.source: Database-Level Firewall Rules
trans-unit.target: Database-Level Firewall Rules

trans-unit.source: After creating a server-level firewall for your IP address, launch a query window through the Management Portal or through SQL Server Management Studio.
trans-unit.target: After creating a server-level firewall for your IP address, launch a query window through the Management Portal or through SQL Server Management Studio.

trans-unit.source: Connect to the database for which you want to create a database-level firewall rule.
trans-unit.target: Connect to the database for which you want to create a database-level firewall rule.

trans-unit.source: To create a new or update an existing database-level firewall rule, execute the sp_set_database_firewall_rule stored procedure.
trans-unit.target: To create a new or update an existing database-level firewall rule, execute the sp_set_database_firewall_rule stored procedure.

trans-unit.source: The following example creates a new firewall rule named ContosoFirewallRule.
trans-unit.target: The following example creates a new firewall rule named ContosoFirewallRule.

trans-unit.source: To delete an existing database-level firewall rule, execute the sp_delete_database_firewall_rule stored procedure.
trans-unit.target: To delete an existing database-level firewall rule, execute the sp_delete_database_firewall_rule stored procedure.

trans-unit.source: The following example deletes the rule named ContosoFirewallRule.
trans-unit.target: The following example deletes the rule named ContosoFirewallRule.
